fields.title: The Story of Coffee: How I Discovered the Magic Beans
fields.content:
The Story of Coffee: How I Discovered the Magic Beans

Greetings! I am Kaldi, a humble goatherd from the highlands of Ethiopia, and I have a story to share that changed the world forever. You see, I am the one who discovered the magic of coffee, a drink that millions of people enjoy every day. Allow me to take you back to the day that altered the course of history, the day I stumbled upon the enchanting beans that would become known as coffee.

A Day Like Any Other

It was an ordinary day in the hills of Ethiopia. The sun was shining brightly, the air was fresh, and my goats were happily grazing on the lush, green pastures. As a goatherd, my life was simple and peaceful. I would lead my flock through the mountains, ensuring they found the best spots to nibble on tender grass and shrubs. My days were routine, but on this particular day, something extraordinary happened.

As I was watching my goats, I noticed they were behaving rather strangely. Normally calm and composed, they were unusually energetic, almost dancing with joy. They were hopping around, bleating loudly, and even chasing each other in playful circles. It was as if they had been possessed by some mysterious force. Curious, I followed them to see what had caused this sudden burst of energy.

The Discovery of the Red Berries

To my surprise, I found my goats gathered around a small shrub bearing bright red berries. They were eagerly nibbling on these berries, their eyes wide with excitement. I had never seen them act this way before. My curiosity piqued, I decided to taste the berries myself. After all, if they had such a remarkable effect on my goats, who knew what they might do for me?

As I bit into one of the berries, I was immediately struck by a burst of flavor. It was unlike anything I had ever tasted—slightly sweet, a bit tart, and altogether invigorating. But the real surprise came moments later when I felt a surge of energy course through my body. My fatigue from the long day of herding vanished, and I felt more alert, more alive than I had in years.

Sharing the Miracle

Excited by my discovery, I gathered a handful of the berries and rushed to the nearest village to share my findings with the local monks. Surely, they would be interested in this miraculous fruit that could banish tiredness and bring such vitality. When I arrived, the monks were skeptical at first, but their curiosity got the better of them. They decided to brew a drink from the berries to see if they could harness the energy I had experienced.

As the fragrant steam rose from the boiling pot, we knew we were onto something special. The monks sipped the brew and were amazed by its effects. Not only did it banish their drowsiness during long nights of prayer, but it also sharpened their minds, helping them focus on their devotions with newfound clarity.

The Birth of a Global Phenomenon

Word of the magical beans spread quickly from village to village, and soon, everyone wanted to experience the energizing effects of the brew. The monks began cultivating the coffee plants, perfecting the process of roasting and brewing the beans to create the rich, aromatic drink we know today.

From the highlands of Ethiopia, the love of coffee spread across the Arabian Peninsula, where it became an integral part of social and religious life. Traders carried it further still, to Europe and beyond, where coffeehouses sprang up, becoming centers of conversation, commerce, and creativity.

A Legacy in Every Cup

Little did I know, on that fateful day, that my goats and I had stumbled upon something that would touch the lives of millions around the globe. Coffee, the humble berry that brought joy to my flock and energy to my soul, has become a beloved daily ritual for countless people. It brings comfort on cold mornings, fuels late-night study sessions, and sparks inspiration in artists, writers, and thinkers.

As you sip your next cup of coffee, think of me, Kaldi, and the joyful dance of my goats in the Ethiopian highlands. Remember the serendipitous discovery that led to the creation of a drink that not only wakes the body but also awakens the spirit. Here's to coffee, the magic beans that continue to bring energy, warmth, and connection to people all over the world.

fields.title: Inventing Coffee Paper Filter
fields.content:
In the early 20th Century, coffee was largely made by placing a cloth bag of coffee grounds in boiling water and waiting. The result, unsurprisingly, was a bitter drink full of grit – very different to your morning coffee.

I hoped to improve on this formula by creating a funnel made of blotting paper, which was then punctured with a thin nail. Hey Presto, the world’s first coffee paper filter was born! This proved immensely popular amongst the working classes who didn’t have access to an Italian espresso machine, and a booming business was formed. By 1918, 100,000 filters had been produced, and production had to be moved to a larger factory to meet demand. By 1950, my business had grown to be worth over £2 million.

fields.title: The Dalgona Coffee Craze: How to Make This Frothy Delight at Home
fields.content:
The Dalgona Coffee Craze: How to Make This Frothy Delight at Home

In the world of coffee, trends come and go, but few have sparked the same level of global enthusiasm as Dalgona coffee. This whipped coffee drink took social media by storm, captivating coffee lovers and casual drinkers alike with its frothy, creamy texture and irresistible flavor. Originating from South Korea, Dalgona coffee quickly became a pandemic-era sensation, offering a comforting cup of caffeine to brighten even the most challenging days. If you’ve yet to try making this delightful beverage at home, now’s the perfect time to dive in. Here’s everything you need to know to make your own Dalgona coffee and understand why it’s become such a beloved treat.

What Is Dalgona Coffee?

Dalgona coffee is a sweet, frothy coffee drink that combines instant coffee, sugar, and hot water, whipped into a creamy foam and served over a glass of cold or hot milk. It’s a simple concept but delivers a complex flavor profile that’s both rich and indulgent. The name "Dalgona" comes from a Korean candy of the same name, which is a sweet, honeycomb-like treat with a slightly caramel flavor, reminiscent of the coffee foam's taste.

The Origins of Dalgona Coffee

Dalgona coffee’s rise to fame is a testament to the power of social media. While the drink has been a popular treat in South Korea for some time, it gained international prominence during the COVID-19 lockdowns in 2020. With people stuck at home and looking for new ways to entertain themselves, the easy-to-make recipe quickly spread across platforms like Instagram and TikTok, with users posting videos of their attempts to create the perfect Dalgona coffee.

How to Make Dalgona Coffee

Creating your own Dalgona coffee at home is surprisingly simple and requires just a few basic ingredients. Here’s a step-by-step guide to help you make your own frothy masterpiece:

Ingredients:

  • 2 tablespoons instant coffee
  • 2 tablespoons granulated sugar
  • 2 tablespoons hot water
  • Milk (any kind you prefer, cold or hot)

Instructions:

  1. Mix the Ingredients: In a medium-sized bowl, combine the instant coffee, granulated sugar, and hot water. The hot water helps to dissolve the coffee and sugar more easily.

  2. Whip the Mixture: Using a hand whisk or an electric mixer, whip the mixture until it becomes thick and creamy. This usually takes about 2-3 minutes with an electric mixer or 5-7 minutes with a hand whisk. The mixture should form stiff peaks, similar to whipped cream.

  3. Prepare the Milk: Pour your choice of milk into a glass. You can use cold milk for a refreshing drink or warm milk for a cozy treat.

  4. Top It Off: Spoon the whipped coffee mixture over the milk, creating a layered effect. You can use a spoon to gently swirl the coffee foam into the milk or leave it layered for a more dramatic presentation.

  5. Enjoy: Stir the whipped coffee into the milk before sipping to fully combine the flavors, or enjoy it as is for a more visually striking drink.

Tips for the Perfect Dalgona Coffee

  • Use Instant Coffee: Dalgona coffee works best with instant coffee due to its solubility, which allows it to whip up into a frothy texture. Regular brewed coffee won’t yield the same results.
  • Adjust Sweetness: Feel free to adjust the amount of sugar according to your taste. You can also experiment with different types of sweeteners if you prefer.
  • Temperature Matters: The hot water should be hot but not boiling. Boiling water can sometimes affect the texture of the foam.

Why Dalgona Coffee is So Special

Beyond its delicious taste and unique texture, Dalgona coffee represents a moment of creativity and comfort during a challenging time. It’s a reminder of how simple pleasures can bring joy and connection, even when we’re physically apart. The process of making Dalgona coffee is as enjoyable as drinking it—watching the transformation from simple ingredients to a fluffy, airy topping is a satisfying experience in itself.

Whether you’re a seasoned coffee aficionado or just looking to try something new, Dalgona coffee is a fun and rewarding way to elevate your daily caffeine routine. So grab your instant coffee and whisk, and dive into the delightful world of Dalgona coffee—you might just find your new favorite treat!


Have you tried making Dalgona coffee? Share your experiences and any tips you’ve discovered along the way in the comments below!

fields.title: What is Coffee?
fields.content:
cof·fee /ˈkôfē,ˈkäfē/  noun  The berries harvested from species of Coffea plants.


Everyone recognizes a roasted coffee bean, but you might not recognize an actual coffee plant. Coffee trees are pruned short to conserve their energy and aid in harvesting, but can grow to more than 30 feet (9 meters) high. Each tree is covered with green, waxy leaves growing opposite each other in pairs. Coffee cherries grow along the branches. Because it grows in a continuous cycle, it’s not unusual to see flowers, green fruit and ripe fruit simultaneously on a single tree.

It takes nearly a year for a cherry to mature after first flowering, and about 5 years of growth to reach full fruit production. While coffee plants can live up to 100 years, they are generally the most productive between the ages of 7 and 20. Proper care can maintain and even increase their output over the years, depending on the variety. The average coffee tree produces 10 pounds of coffee cherry per year, or 2 pounds of green beans.

All commercially grown coffee is from a region of the world called the Coffee Belt. The trees grow best in rich soil, with mild temperatures, frequent rain and shaded sun.

Botanical classification

Coffee traces its origin to a genus of plants known as Coffea.  Within the genus there are over 500 genera and 6,000 species of tropical trees and shrubs. Experts estimate that there are anywhere from 25 to 100 species of coffee plants.

The genus was first described in the 18th century by the Swedish botanist, Carolus Linneaus, who also described Coffea Arabica in his Species Plantarum in 1753. Botanists have disagreed ever since on the exact classification, since coffee plants can range widely. They can be small shrubs to tall trees, with leaves from one to 16 inches in size, and in colors from purple or yellow to the predominant dark green.

In the commercial coffee industry, there are two important coffee species — Arabica and Robusta.

Coffea Arabica — C. Arabica 

Varieties: Bourbon, Typica, Caturra, Mundo Novo, Tico, San Ramon, Jamaican Blue Mountain

Coffea Arabica is descended from the original coffee trees discovered in Ethiopia.  These trees produce a fine, mild, aromatic coffee and represent approximately 70% of the world's coffee production. The beans are flatter and more elongated than Robusta and lower in caffeine.

On the world market, Arabica coffees bring the highest prices.  The better Arabicas are high grown coffees — generally grown between 2,000 to 6,000 feet (610 to 1830 meters) above sea level — though optimal altitude varies with proximity to the equator. 

The most important factor is that temperatures must remain mild, ideally between 59 - 75 degrees Fahrenheit, with about 60 inches of rainfall a year. The trees are hearty, but a heavy frost will kill them.  

Arabica trees are costly to cultivate because the ideal terrain tends to be steep and access is difficult. Also, because the trees are more disease-prone than Robusta, they require additional care and attention. 

 

Coffea canephora — C. canephora var. Robusta

Variety: Robusta

Most of the world's Robusta is grown in Central and Western Africa, parts of Southeast Asia, including Indonesia and Vietnam, and in Brazil. Production of Robusta is increasing, though it accounts for only about 30% of the world market. 

Robusta is primarily used in blends and for instant coffees. The Robusta bean itself tends to be slightly rounder and smaller than an Arabica bean.  

The Robusta tree is heartier and more resistant to disease and parasites, which makes it easier and cheaper to cultivate. It also has the advantage of being able to withstand warmer climates, preferring constant temperatures between 75 and 85 degrees Fahrenheit, which enables it to grow at far lower altitudes than Arabica.  

It requires about 60 inches of rainfall a year, and cannot withstand frost. Compared with Arabica, Robusta beans produce a coffee which has a distinctive taste and about 50-60% more caffeine.  

The Anatomy of a Coffee Cherry

The beans you brew are actually the processed and roasted seeds from a fruit, which is called a coffee cherry.

The coffee cherry's outer skin is called the exocarp. Beneath it is the mesocarp, a thin layer of pulp, followed by a slimy layer called the parenchyma.  The beans themselves are covered in a paper-like envelope named the endocarp, more commonly referred to as the parchment.  

Inside the parchment, side-by-side, lie two beans, each covered separately by yet another thin membrane. The biological name for this seed skin is the spermoderm, but it is generally referred to in the coffee trade as the silver skin.

In about 5% of the world's coffee, there is only one bean inside the cherry. This is called a peaberry (or a caracol, or "snail" in Spanish), and it is a natural mutation. Some people believe that peaberries are actually sweeter and more flavorful than standard beans, so they are sometimes manually sorted out for special sale.

Credit: National Coffee Association of U.S.A

fields.title: The Origins of Coffee: From Mystical Beginnings to Global Obsession
fields.content:
The Origins of Coffee: From Mystical Beginnings to Global Obsession

Introduction

Coffee, the beloved brew that kickstarts our mornings and fuels late-night creativity, has a rich and fascinating history that spans centuries. From its mystical origins in the highlands of Ethiopia to its current status as a global commodity, coffee has evolved into more than just a drink—it's a cultural phenomenon. Join us as we explore the origins of coffee, tracing its journey from a simple bean to the centerpiece of coffeehouses worldwide.

The Legend of Kaldi and the Dancing Goats

The story of coffee’s discovery is steeped in legend. According to popular folklore, the origins of coffee can be traced back to the 9th century in Ethiopia. A young goat herder named Kaldi noticed that his goats were unusually energetic after eating the red cherries from a certain tree. Curious, Kaldi tried the cherries himself and experienced the same burst of energy. Excited by his discovery, he brought the cherries to a local monastery.

The monks, initially skeptical, found that the cherries helped them stay awake during long hours of prayer. The knowledge of this miraculous plant began to spread across the region, and soon, coffee became a staple in religious rituals, helping monks maintain focus and alertness during their devotions.

The Journey to Arabia: The Birthplace of Coffee Culture

Coffee’s journey continued from Ethiopia to the Arabian Peninsula, where it truly began to flourish. By the 15th century, coffee was being cultivated and traded in the Yemeni port city of Mocha. It was in Arabia that coffee became more than just a stimulating beverage—it became a cultural cornerstone.

In the city of Mecca, coffeehouses known as "qahveh khaneh" began to emerge, serving as places of social interaction, intellectual exchange, and political discussion. These coffeehouses quickly spread throughout the Middle East, Persia, and North Africa, becoming hubs of conversation and community life. Coffee’s popularity in these regions was so profound that it became known as the "wine of Arabia," and its consumption was intertwined with religious and social practices.

Coffee’s European Debut

The story of coffee’s spread to Europe is one of intrigue and fascination. Venetian traders, who had established trade routes with the Middle East, were among the first Europeans to encounter coffee. By the 17th century, coffee had made its way to the European continent, where it quickly gained popularity in major cities like Venice, London, and Paris.

However, coffee’s arrival in Europe was met with some resistance. The beverage was initially viewed with suspicion and even referred to as the "bitter invention of Satan" by some clergy. But when Pope Clement VIII was asked to condemn coffee, he instead blessed it, allegedly stating, "This devil’s drink is so delicious that it would be a pity to let the infidels have exclusive use of it." With this papal approval, coffee’s reputation soared, and coffeehouses began to proliferate across Europe.

The Coffeehouse Culture and the Enlightenment

The European coffeehouse culture became synonymous with the intellectual and social movements of the time. In England, coffeehouses were dubbed "penny universities" because for the price of a penny, one could gain access to stimulating conversation and news. These establishments became gathering places for writers, artists, scientists, and philosophers, playing a crucial role in the dissemination of ideas during the Enlightenment.

Notable figures like Isaac Newton, Samuel Johnson, and Voltaire were regulars at coffeehouses, where they engaged in discussions that shaped the intellectual landscape of the era. Coffeehouses also became the birthplace of newspapers and financial institutions, with Lloyd's of London famously starting as a coffeehouse.

Coffee Goes Global: The Birth of an Industry

As the demand for coffee grew, European colonial powers began to establish coffee plantations in their colonies. The Dutch were among the first to cultivate coffee in Java, Indonesia, while the French introduced coffee to the Caribbean and South America. Brazil, which would later become the largest coffee producer in the world, saw its first coffee plants in the early 18th century.

The global expansion of coffee cultivation transformed it into one of the most valuable commodities in the world. Coffee became an integral part of the economies of countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America, shaping the agricultural and social landscapes of these regions.

Conclusion

The journey of coffee from the Ethiopian highlands to your morning cup is a testament to its enduring appeal and cultural significance. From its mystical beginnings with Kaldi and the dancing goats to its role in the intellectual ferment of European coffeehouses, coffee has become more than just a beverage—it’s a symbol of connection, conversation, and creativity. So, the next time you sip your favorite brew, take a moment to appreciate the rich history behind those aromatic beans.

fields.title: Coffee Cake Recipe
fields.content:
﻿Coffee Cake


Whip up a classic coffee cake with ease. You can freeze the sponges if you want to save time later on. Ideal for a bake sale, birthday party or coffee morning


Ingredients

  • 170g butter or margarine, plus extra for the tins
  • 170g caster sugar
  • 3 large eggs
  • 170g self-raising flour
  • 1 tbsp cooled instant coffee, dissolved in 1 tbsp hot water (add more if you like it stronger)
  • For the icing
  • 225g icing sugar
  • 100g butter or margarine
  • 1½ tbsp instant coffee, dissolved in 1 tbsp hot water
  • strawberry jam (optional)
  • walnuts or cherries, to decorate (optional)

Method

STEP 1

Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan. Line and butter two 18cm sandwich tins. Add the sugar and butter to a bowl and whisk until very fluffy and pale.


STEP 2

Whisk the eggs in a mug with a fork, then add them gradually to the mixture with 1 tbsp of flour each time. (Make sure you don't use all the flour.) When the eggs have been fully combined into the mix, add the rest of the flour and fold it in gently.


STEP 3

Add the dissolved coffee to the mixture, still folding. Divide into the sandwich tins and cook for 25-30 min until risen and firm and a skewer inserted into the middle comes out clean. Leave to cool in the tin for 5 mins then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely. Can be frozen at this stage.


STEP 4

Meanwhile, make the icing by beating the icing sugar with the butter until light and fluffy, then add the dissolved coffee. Whisk, then cover and set aside until ready to ice the cake.


STEP 5

Spread half the icing on the bottom of one sponge and spread the strawberry jam on the bottom of the other, if using. Sandwich together, then spread the remaining icing on top. Decorate with walnuts or cherries, if you like.



Credit: BBC Good Food

fields.title: La Dolce Vita: My Journey as an Italian Coffee Connoisseur
fields.content:
La Dolce Vita: My Journey as an Italian Coffee Connoisseur

Buongiorno! I am Leo Venti, an Italian coffee connoisseur with a passion for the art, culture, and tradition that surrounds one of Italy’s most cherished treasures—coffee. To me, coffee is more than just a drink; it’s a symbol of our way of life, an expression of our culture, and a ritual that punctuates our day with moments of pleasure and reflection.

The Roots of Italian Coffee Culture

In Italy, coffee is not simply consumed; it’s celebrated. Our history with coffee dates back centuries, with the first coffee house opening in Venice in 1683. Since then, coffee has woven itself into the fabric of our daily lives. The Italian coffee culture is steeped in tradition, yet it evolves with each generation, maintaining its authenticity while embracing innovation.

For us Italians, the day begins with a caffè—a shot of espresso, sipped quickly at the bar, often accompanied by a cornetto. This isn’t just about caffeine; it’s about the experience, the social interaction, the ritual of starting the day in a communal space. From there, coffee breaks punctuate the day, each with its own specific purpose and meaning.

The Art of Espresso

To truly appreciate Italian coffee, one must understand the art of espresso. The perfect espresso is a balance of science and passion. The beans must be freshly ground, the water temperature precise, and the pressure exact. But beyond the technical details lies the heart of the matter—the passion for creating a small yet powerful beverage that embodies the essence of coffee.

When I prepare an espresso, it’s a moment of reverence. I watch as the golden crema forms, the aroma fills the air, and the deep, rich flavors come alive with that first sip. It’s a moment to pause, appreciate, and savor—an experience that connects me to my roots, to the history of Italian coffee masters, and to the countless people who share this love.

Espresso’s Cousins: Cappuccino and Beyond

Of course, espresso has given birth to a family of drinks that are equally beloved in Italy. The cappuccino, a perfect blend of espresso, steamed milk, and froth, is a morning staple, though only until 11 AM—any time after that, and you’ll stand out as a tourist! The macchiato, with just a dash of milk, and the ristretto, an even more concentrated shot of espresso, offer variations that cater to different tastes and moments of the day.

In recent years, we’ve also seen the rise of newer coffee trends in Italy—like the caffè shakerato, a chilled, shaken espresso, and specialty coffees that explore different origins, roasts, and brewing methods. These innovations are welcomed, but always with respect to the traditions that define our coffee culture.

The Café as a Cultural Hub

In Italy, the café, or bar, is much more than a place to grab a quick coffee. It’s a cultural hub, a place where people meet, converse, and connect. From the bustling morning rush to the quiet afternoon lull, the barista knows each customer’s preferences, creating a sense of community that’s as warm as the coffee they serve.

For me, visiting a bar is a daily ritual. It’s where I catch up with friends, discuss the day’s news, and take a moment to enjoy the simple pleasure of a well-made coffee. Whether in the heart of Rome or a small village in Tuscany, the bar is a reflection of our way of life—unhurried, connected, and filled with small joys.

The Future of Italian Coffee

As a connoisseur, I’ve seen how Italian coffee culture has both preserved its traditions and embraced change. The world of coffee is evolving, with new brewing techniques, flavors, and trends emerging every day. Yet, what remains constant is the Italian commitment to quality, authenticity, and the social experience of coffee.

Looking ahead, I’m excited about the future of Italian coffee. We are seeing a renewed interest in sustainability, with more attention being paid to where our beans come from and how they are grown. At the same time, young baristas are bringing fresh energy and creativity to the craft, experimenting with flavors and techniques while respecting the foundations of Italian coffee-making.

As I continue my journey through the world of coffee, I remain dedicated to sharing the beauty of Italian coffee culture with others. Whether through tastings, workshops, or simply sharing a cup with friends, I hope to inspire others to appreciate the artistry and tradition that makes Italian coffee so special.

So, next time you sip an espresso, take a moment to savor not just the flavor, but the history, the craft, and the passion behind it. After all, in Italy, coffee is not just a drink—it’s a way of life.

Salute,
Leo Venti

fields.title: How Coffee Influences Productivity & Creativity
fields.content:
How Coffee Influences Productivity & Creativity


Coffee has long been associated with productivity and creativity, serving as a staple in workplaces, studios, and homes around the world. Here’s how coffee influences both:

1. Boosting Alertness and Focus

Coffee is rich in caffeine, a natural stimulant that blocks adenosine receptors in the brain, preventing the onset of drowsiness. This leads to increased alertness, making it easier to focus on tasks that require sustained concentration. Many studies have shown that moderate caffeine consumption can improve attention, reaction times, and cognitive function, which are essential for productivity.

2. Enhancing Memory and Learning

Caffeine has been found to improve both short-term memory and learning capabilities. This effect is particularly useful in environments that require the absorption and retention of information, such as studying or attending meetings. Enhanced memory can directly contribute to better productivity, as individuals can more effectively recall and utilize information.

3. Stimulating Creativity

Creativity often requires a relaxed, yet alert state of mind—a balance that coffee can help achieve. The stimulation from caffeine, coupled with the ritualistic nature of drinking coffee, can create a conducive environment for creative thinking. Many creatives report that the act of sipping coffee during brainstorming sessions or creative work can help in generating ideas and overcoming mental blocks.

4. Mood Elevation

Caffeine stimulates the release of dopamine, the “feel-good” neurotransmitter. This can lead to improved mood and a more positive outlook, which is beneficial in both collaborative and solitary work environments. A better mood not only boosts productivity but also fosters a more creative and open-minded approach to problem-solving.

5. Social Interaction and Collaboration

Coffee often serves as a social lubricant in workplaces and creative spaces. The coffee break is more than just a moment to recharge; it’s a time for informal discussions, networking, and collaboration. These interactions can lead to the exchange of ideas and inspiration, further fueling creativity and collective productivity.

6. Reducing Fatigue

By combating fatigue, coffee helps maintain productivity levels throughout the day. This is especially important in tasks that require prolonged attention and can prevent the mid-afternoon slump, which is a common productivity killer.

7. Balancing Caffeine Intake

While coffee can enhance productivity and creativity, it’s important to note that excessive consumption can lead to jitteriness, anxiety, and disrupted sleep patterns, all of which can have the opposite effect. Finding the right balance is key to leveraging coffee’s benefits without suffering from its downsides.

In conclusion, coffee, when consumed in moderation, is a powerful tool for boosting both productivity and creativity. Its effects on alertness, memory, mood, and social interaction make it an indispensable part of many people's daily routines.

fields.title: A Brew of Her Own: The Story of Ava Brewster in the World of Coffee
fields.content:
﻿A Brew of Her Own: The Story of Ava Brewster in the World of Coffee

My name is Ava Brewster, and my journey into the world of coffee is as rich and complex as the brews I craft. Coffee isn’t just a beverage; it’s a story, an art, and a passion that has shaped my life in ways I could never have imagined.

The Early Days: A Simple Beginning

Growing up, coffee was a constant presence in my home, but it was more than just a morning ritual. I remember the aroma of freshly ground beans filling the kitchen, signaling the start of the day. My fascination with coffee began at a young age, not just as a drink but as a culture, a community, and a form of expression. However, I never imagined that it would become my life's work.

Discovering My Path

My real journey into the world of coffee started when I took a job as a barista in a small café during college. What began as a means to pay the bills soon turned into a deep passion. I was captivated by the nuances of coffee-making—the science behind the perfect extraction, the art of latte design, and the way a well-crafted cup could bring a moment of joy to someone’s day.

But my curiosity didn’t stop at the espresso machine. I wanted to understand the entire process, from the farm to the cup. This led me to travel, visiting coffee farms and learning from the growers themselves. I realized that each cup of coffee carries a story—the hard work of the farmers, the care in roasting, and the precision in brewing. This understanding deepened my respect for the craft and solidified my desire to be a part of this industry.

Building a Career in Coffee

After years of honing my skills and learning from some of the best in the industry, I knew it was time to create something of my own. I wanted to build a brand that not only offered great coffee but also told the stories behind each bean. That’s when I decided to launch my own coffee company.

Starting a business wasn’t easy, especially in such a competitive market. But I believed in my vision—a company that focused on sustainability, fair trade, and quality. I wanted to connect consumers with the origins of their coffee, to make them aware of the journey their cup has taken. Every decision I made, from sourcing beans to designing packaging, was driven by this purpose.

Challenges and Triumphs

The road hasn’t always been smooth. Building a brand from the ground up comes with its share of challenges—financial pressures, supply chain issues, and the constant need to innovate. But every setback has been a learning experience, shaping me into the entrepreneur I am today.

One of the most rewarding aspects of my journey has been the community I’ve built. Coffee has a unique way of bringing people together, and I’ve been fortunate to meet and collaborate with incredible individuals who share my passion. Whether it’s through coffee cuppings, workshops, or simply conversations over a cup of coffee, I’ve found a network of support and inspiration.

Looking to the Future

As I continue to grow my brand, my mission remains the same: to create exceptional coffee that tells a story. I’m constantly exploring new trends, such as sustainability practices, plant-based innovations, and technology in coffee brewing. But at the heart of it all, I’m committed to maintaining the integrity and quality that coffee deserves.

My journey is far from over, and I’m excited about what the future holds. Coffee is a constantly evolving landscape, and I’m here for the ride, eager to discover, create, and share the next chapter of this incredible story.

So, here’s to coffee—the drink that fuels our dreams, connects us to the world, and reminds us that the best stories are the ones we share with others.

fields.title: The Industrialization of Coffee
fields.content:
The Industrialization of Coffee


The industrialization of coffee refers to the transformation of coffee production, processing, and distribution from traditional, small-scale methods to large-scale, mechanized processes driven by technological advancements and global demand. This shift has had significant implications for the coffee industry, including increased efficiency, changes in labor practices, environmental impacts, and shifts in global trade dynamics.

1. Mechanization of Coffee Production

In the early stages of coffee production, coffee beans were harvested, processed, and roasted using manual labor and simple tools. However, as global demand for coffee grew, particularly during the 19th and 20th centuries, there was a push towards mechanization to increase output and reduce costs. This included the development of machinery for planting, harvesting, and processing coffee beans, such as mechanical harvesters, wet mills for pulping coffee cherries, and large-scale roasting equipment.

2. Global Supply Chains

Industrialization facilitated the development of complex global supply chains that enabled coffee to be grown in tropical regions (mainly in the Global South) and consumed predominantly in the Global North. Multinational corporations played a crucial role in this process, establishing vast networks for the sourcing, processing, and distribution of coffee. This shift allowed coffee to become a ubiquitous commodity, but it also led to the concentration of power among a few large companies, often at the expense of smallholder farmers.

3. Impact on Coffee Farmers

The industrialization of coffee has had mixed effects on coffee farmers. On one hand, it has provided access to larger markets and increased productivity. On the other hand, it has often led to the commoditization of coffee, where farmers receive a lower share of the final product’s value. The focus on efficiency and cost reduction has sometimes resulted in exploitative labor practices and a lack of investment in the well-being of coffee-growing communities.

4. Environmental Consequences

Industrialized coffee production has also had significant environmental impacts. The shift towards monoculture farming and the use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides has led to deforestation, soil degradation, and loss of biodiversity in many coffee-growing regions. Additionally, the demand for high-yield coffee varieties has sometimes displaced traditional, shade-grown coffee, which is generally more sustainable.

5. The Rise of Instant Coffee and Mass Production

A key development in the industrialization of coffee was the invention of instant coffee in the early 20th century. Companies like Nestlé pioneered this segment, making coffee consumption more convenient and accessible, especially during and after World War II. Instant coffee production is highly industrialized, involving freeze-drying or spray-drying processes that allow coffee to be preserved and transported over long distances with minimal loss of flavor.

6. Sustainability and Ethical Concerns

In recent decades, there has been a growing awareness of the downsides of industrialized coffee production, leading to movements towards sustainability and fair trade. These initiatives aim to ensure better wages and working conditions for coffee farmers, reduce environmental harm, and promote more equitable trading practices. Certifications like Fair Trade, Rainforest Alliance, and Organic have become increasingly important in the coffee industry, reflecting consumer demand for ethically sourced products.

7. Technological Innovation and the Future

As the coffee industry continues to evolve, new technologies are being developed to address some of the challenges associated with industrialization. These include precision agriculture techniques that optimize resource use, blockchain for transparent supply chains, and advances in coffee processing that enhance quality while reducing environmental impact.

The industrialization of coffee has transformed the way coffee is produced, distributed, and consumed globally. While it has brought about significant advancements in efficiency and accessibility, it has also introduced complex challenges related to social equity, environmental sustainability, and the concentration of power within the industry.

fields.title: The Impact of Climate Change on Coffee Production
fields.content:
The Impact of Climate Change on Coffee Production

1. Rising Temperatures

Coffee plants, particularly the Arabica variety, thrive in specific climate conditions, typically at higher altitudes where temperatures are cooler. As global temperatures rise, these ideal growing conditions are shifting. In some regions, farmers are forced to move their crops to higher altitudes, but this isn't always possible due to geographic limitations. Higher temperatures also stress the plants, leading to lower yields and poorer quality beans.

2. Changing Rainfall Patterns

Coffee crops are highly sensitive to changes in rainfall. Too much or too little rain can have devastating effects. In many coffee-growing regions, climate change is causing more erratic rainfall patterns, including prolonged droughts or excessive rainfall. Droughts can lead to water scarcity, stunting plant growth, while heavy rains can increase the risk of diseases like coffee leaf rust and reduce the quality of the beans.

3. Increased Pest and Disease Pressure

Warmer temperatures and changing humidity levels create more favorable conditions for pests and diseases that affect coffee plants. For instance, the coffee berry borer, a pest that destroys coffee beans, is spreading to higher altitudes where it previously could not survive. Similarly, coffee leaf rust, a fungal disease, is becoming more prevalent, decimating crops in some regions and leading to significant economic losses.

4. Threats to Coffee-Growing Regions

Some of the world’s most famous coffee-growing regions are under threat due to climate change. Countries like Brazil, Ethiopia, and Colombia, which are major coffee producers, are facing changes in their microclimates. In some areas, coffee production may become untenable, forcing farmers to either adapt their practices, switch crops, or abandon coffee farming altogether.

5. Economic and Social Impact

The impacts of climate change on coffee production have significant economic and social implications. Millions of smallholder farmers depend on coffee as their primary source of income. Reduced yields and lower quality beans mean less income, which can drive poverty and exacerbate social issues in coffee-growing communities. Additionally, the rising costs associated with adapting to climate change—such as investing in new technologies or moving farms—are often beyond the reach of small-scale farmers.

6. Sustainability Efforts

In response to these challenges, the coffee industry is increasingly focusing on sustainability. This includes developing more resilient coffee plant varieties, promoting agroforestry (which integrates coffee plants with other crops or trees), and implementing practices that conserve water and soil. However, these efforts require substantial investment and cooperation across the supply chain.

The future of coffee production is uncertain, but it is clear that climate change is reshaping the industry. Without significant action, both in mitigating climate change and adapting farming practices, the world could face a future where coffee becomes scarcer and more expensive.

fields.title: Coffee Trends 2024
fields.content:
Coffee Trends 2024

In 2024, the coffee industry is witnessing some fascinating trends driven by innovation, health consciousness, and sustainability. Here’s a breakdown of what’s shaping the coffee world this year:

  1. Infused and Functional Coffees: Health-focused coffee options are rising in popularity, with mushroom-infused coffee and vitamin-enriched blends leading the way. These beverages cater to consumers looking for more than just caffeine, offering additional health benefits like enhanced focus and immunity boosts.

  2. Technology-Driven Experiences: Smart coffee machines are becoming mainstream, allowing users to personalize their brews with precision and even control their coffee-making remotely via apps. AI-driven systems are also improving the quality and consistency of coffee by optimizing roasting processes and tailoring brewing methods to individual preferences.

  3. Sustainability and Ethical Sourcing: Environmental and ethical concerns are at the forefront, with a strong emphasis on transparency in sourcing and the reduction of carbon footprints. Coffee brands are increasingly expected to demonstrate their commitment to sustainability, from farm to cup.

  4. Plant-Based Milks: The demand for non-dairy alternatives continues to grow, with oat, almond, and coconut milk among the most popular choices. These options cater to dietary restrictions and preferences, offering a wider array of flavors and textures.

  5. Ready-to-Drink (RTD) and Snapchilled Coffee: Convenience is king, and RTD coffee beverages, especially those featuring innovative snapchilling processes, are gaining traction. These drinks offer the freshness and flavor of freshly brewed coffee in a grab-and-go format.

  6. Specialty and Asian Coffees: There is a growing interest in specialty coffees, particularly those sourced from Asian countries like Thailand, where unique varieties and processing methods are gaining international recognition. This reflects a broader trend of consumers seeking unique and high-quality coffee experiences.

fields.title: The Health Benefits of Coffee: More Than Just a Morning Boost
fields.content:
The Health Benefits of Coffee: More Than Just a Morning Boost

For many of us, coffee is an essential part of our daily routine—a morning ritual that helps us start the day on the right foot. But beyond its ability to wake us up, coffee offers a range of health benefits that make it more than just a caffeine fix. Here’s a quick look at some of the positive impacts coffee can have on your health.

1. Rich in Antioxidants

Coffee is packed with antioxidants, which are compounds that help protect your cells from damage caused by free radicals. In fact, for many people, coffee is one of the largest sources of antioxidants in their diet, even more so than fruits and vegetables.

2. Boosts Mental Alertness and Focus

The caffeine in coffee is a well-known stimulant that can enhance brain function. It helps improve focus, alertness, and cognitive performance, making it easier to tackle tasks that require concentration and mental clarity.

3. May Reduce the Risk of Certain Diseases

Research has shown that regular coffee consumption may be linked to a lower risk of several chronic diseases. Studies suggest that coffee drinkers have a reduced risk of developing type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease. Coffee may also protect the liver, with some research indicating a lower risk of liver conditions like cirrhosis and liver cancer.

4. Supports Heart Health

Moderate coffee consumption has been associated with a lower risk of heart disease and stroke. The key here is moderation—about 3-4 cups a day appears to be the sweet spot for reaping these heart-healthy benefits.

5. Enhances Physical Performance

Caffeine is known to boost physical performance by increasing adrenaline levels, which prepares your body for intense physical exertion. It can also help break down body fat, making fatty acids available for use as energy. This is why a cup of coffee before a workout can give you an extra boost in endurance and strength.

Conclusion: Enjoy in Moderation

While coffee offers numerous health benefits, it's important to enjoy it in moderation. Too much caffeine can lead to jitteriness, insomnia, and an increased heart rate. But when consumed responsibly, coffee can be a delightful and healthful addition to your daily routine. So, go ahead—savor that cup of coffee, knowing it’s doing more than just waking you up!

fields.title: Essential Coffee Gear and Gadgets: Elevate Your Home Brewing Game
fields.content:
Essential Coffee Gear and Gadgets: Elevate Your Home Brewing Game

For coffee enthusiasts, brewing the perfect cup of coffee is both an art and a science. While the quality of your coffee beans plays a crucial role, having the right gear and gadgets can make all the difference in your brewing experience. Whether you're just starting your journey into the world of coffee or you're looking to upgrade your setup, here’s a guide to the essential coffee gear and gadgets that will help you brew like a pro.

1. The Coffee Grinder: Freshness is Key

One of the most important investments you can make in your coffee setup is a quality grinder. Freshly ground coffee is essential for achieving the best flavor, as pre-ground coffee quickly loses its aroma and taste.

  • Blade Grinder: A more affordable option, blade grinders use rotating blades to chop the coffee beans. While they are budget-friendly, they can produce uneven grind sizes, leading to an inconsistent brew.

  • Burr Grinder: A burr grinder, whether manual or electric, is the gold standard for coffee enthusiasts. It crushes the beans between two burrs, resulting in a uniform grind size. This consistency is key for achieving a balanced extraction and, ultimately, a better cup of coffee.

Pro Tip: Opt for a burr grinder with adjustable settings so you can easily switch between grind sizes for different brewing methods, from espresso to French press.

2. Coffee Scale: Precision Brewing

A coffee scale may seem like an unnecessary gadget, but for serious coffee lovers, it’s a game-changer. Measuring your coffee and water by weight rather than volume ensures precision and consistency, which are crucial for a balanced brew.

  • Digital Coffee Scale: Look for a scale that is accurate to within 0.1 grams and has a built-in timer. This will help you measure both your coffee grounds and brewing time, giving you full control over the brewing process.

Pro Tip: Use a ratio of 1:15 to 1:17 coffee to water (e.g., 20 grams of coffee for 300 grams of water) for the perfect cup, adjusting based on your taste preferences.

3. Pour-Over Kettle: Mastering the Pour

For those who love the precision of the pour-over method, a pour-over kettle, often called a gooseneck kettle, is a must-have. The long, narrow spout allows you to control the flow of water, ensuring an even saturation of the coffee grounds.

  • Electric Gooseneck Kettle: Many electric gooseneck kettles come with adjustable temperature settings, allowing you to heat your water to the ideal brewing temperature (usually between 195°F and 205°F).

  • Stovetop Gooseneck Kettle: A stovetop version offers similar control but without the convenience of precise temperature settings.

Pro Tip: Water temperature can significantly impact the flavor of your coffee. Too hot, and you risk over-extraction and bitterness; too cool, and you may end up with a weak, under-extracted brew.

4. French Press: Bold and Simple

The French press is a classic and simple way to brew a rich, full-bodied cup of coffee. Its design is straightforward, but the results are anything but basic. A French press is a great addition to any coffee lover’s gear collection, particularly for those who enjoy a strong brew.

  • Glass French Press: The most common type, offering a clear view of the brewing process. Just be careful with temperature changes to avoid cracking.

  • Stainless Steel French Press: More durable and often insulated to keep your coffee hot for longer, stainless steel presses are perfect for those who prioritize both function and form.

Pro Tip: Use a coarse grind and steep the coffee for about four minutes before pressing the plunger down slowly to avoid over-extraction.

5. Espresso Machine: Crafting the Perfect Shot

If you’re a fan of espresso, investing in a quality espresso machine can take your home brewing to the next level. Espresso machines range from manual to fully automatic, each offering different levels of control over the brewing process.

  • Manual Espresso Machine: Offers full control over every aspect of the shot, from grind size to pressure. It’s perfect for purists who enjoy the craft of making espresso.

  • Semi-Automatic Espresso Machine: Balances control and convenience, allowing you to tamp the grounds and start the shot manually but automating the water pressure and temperature.

  • Fully Automatic Espresso Machine: Handles the entire process for you, from grinding the beans to pulling the shot, making it ideal for those who want great espresso with minimal effort.

Pro Tip: Keep your espresso machine well-maintained by regularly cleaning the portafilter, group head, and steam wand to ensure consistent quality.

6. AeroPress: Versatile and Portable

The AeroPress is a versatile, portable coffee maker that’s beloved for its ability to brew a variety of coffee styles, from strong, espresso-like shots to smooth, American-style coffee. It’s perfect for coffee lovers who enjoy experimenting with different brewing techniques or need a travel-friendly option.

  • Classic AeroPress: Simple and durable, the classic AeroPress is easy to use and clean, making it a great choice for both beginners and seasoned coffee enthusiasts.

  • AeroPress Go: A more compact version of the original, designed specifically for travel, complete with its own mug and carrying case.

Pro Tip: Experiment with different grind sizes, brew times, and water temperatures to find your perfect AeroPress recipe. The possibilities are nearly endless!

7. Cold Brew Maker: Smooth and Refreshing

Cold brew coffee is a refreshing way to enjoy your coffee, especially during warmer months. While you can make cold brew with any container, dedicated cold brew makers simplify the process and often produce better results.

  • Cold Brew Pitcher: These typically come with a built-in filter, making it easy to steep coffee grounds in cold water for 12-24 hours. They’re perfect for making a batch of cold brew that you can store in the fridge for days.

  • Immersion Cold Brew Maker: Some cold brew makers use immersion methods to produce a more concentrated coffee, which can be diluted with water or milk.

Pro Tip: Use a coarse grind and a 1:4 coffee-to-water ratio for a concentrated brew. Dilute it to taste with water or milk after steeping.

8. Milk Frother: Creating Café-Style Drinks at Home

If you enjoy lattes, cappuccinos, or any other coffee drink that requires frothed milk, a milk frother is a handy gadget to have in your kitchen.

  • Handheld Milk Frother: Affordable and easy to use, these battery-operated frothers are great for quickly frothing milk for your favorite drinks.

  • Electric Milk Frother: These frothers heat and froth the milk at the same time, offering a more consistent and creamier texture compared to handheld versions.

Pro Tip: For the best results, use cold milk straight from the fridge, and opt for whole milk or oat milk for a creamier froth.

Conclusion: Gear Up for Better Coffee

Investing in quality coffee gear and gadgets can elevate your home brewing experience, allowing you to craft a cup of coffee that rivals your favorite café. Whether you’re looking for precision with a digital scale, the versatility of an AeroPress, or the boldness of a French press, the right tools can make all the difference. So, explore these gadgets, experiment with different techniques, and enjoy the journey to finding your perfect cup of coffee!

fields.title: The Ultimate Guide to Coffee Brewing Methods: Finding Your Perfect Cup
fields.content:
The Ultimate Guide to Coffee Brewing Methods: Finding Your Perfect Cup

When it comes to brewing coffee, there’s no one-size-fits-all method. Each brewing technique brings out different flavors and characteristics from the coffee beans, allowing you to tailor your cup to your personal taste. Whether you’re a coffee aficionado or a casual drinker looking to up your game, exploring different brewing methods is a journey worth taking. Let’s dive into some popular coffee brewing methods and discover how each can transform your morning ritual.

1. The Classic Drip Coffee Maker

Overview: The drip coffee maker is a staple in many households and offices. It’s convenient, easy to use, and can brew multiple cups at once.

Best For: Those who want a straightforward, consistent cup of coffee without much fuss.

How It Works: Ground coffee is placed in a filter, hot water is poured over it, and the brewed coffee drips into a carafe. The machine controls the water temperature and flow, making it a reliable option for busy mornings.

Flavor Profile: Drip coffee typically produces a balanced, mild flavor. While it may not highlight the nuances of specialty beans, it’s perfect for a smooth and dependable cup.

Pro Tip: Use a medium grind size for your coffee, and ensure your water-to-coffee ratio is around 1:15 to 1:17 for optimal flavor.

2. French Press: Rich and Full-Bodied

Overview: The French press, also known as a press pot or plunger pot, is a popular choice for those who love a strong, full-bodied coffee.

Best For: Coffee lovers who enjoy a rich, robust flavor with a bit of texture.

How It Works: Coarsely ground coffee is steeped in hot water for about four minutes, then separated by pressing a metal or mesh plunger through the liquid.

Flavor Profile: The French press allows more of the coffee's natural oils and fine particles to remain in the brew, resulting in a richer and more complex cup.

Pro Tip: To avoid a gritty taste, pour your coffee slowly and stop before you reach the last bit of liquid in the press.

3. Pour-Over: Precision Brewing

Overview: The pour-over method is beloved by coffee purists for its precision and ability to highlight the delicate flavors in high-quality beans.

Best For: Those who appreciate the artistry of brewing and want to savor the nuanced flavors of specialty coffee.

How It Works: Hot water is poured over coffee grounds in a circular motion, allowing the water to filter through the grounds at a controlled pace. This method requires a bit of patience and skill to perfect.

Flavor Profile: Pour-over coffee is often bright and clean, with a clarity of flavor that showcases the beans' unique characteristics.

Pro Tip: Use a gooseneck kettle for more precise control over the pour, and aim for a brewing time of about 3-4 minutes.

4. AeroPress: Versatile and Quick

Overview: The AeroPress is a relatively new brewing method that has gained a cult following for its versatility and speed. It’s a great option for those who want a single cup of coffee that’s full of flavor.

Best For: Adventurous coffee drinkers who enjoy experimenting with brewing techniques.

How It Works: Coffee grounds and hot water are steeped in a chamber for 30-60 seconds, then pressed through a filter using air pressure. The result is a concentrated coffee that can be enjoyed as is or diluted with water or milk.

Flavor Profile: AeroPress coffee is smooth, rich, and less acidic than many other brewing methods. It’s a great middle ground between a French press and an espresso.

Pro Tip: Experiment with different grind sizes, brew times, and water temperatures to find your perfect cup. The possibilities are endless!

5. Espresso: Intense and Bold

Overview: Espresso is a concentrated coffee brewed by forcing hot water through finely-ground coffee under high pressure. It’s the base for many popular coffee drinks, including lattes, cappuccinos, and macchiatos.

Best For: Those who love a strong, bold coffee with a rich crema on top.

How It Works: An espresso machine pushes hot water through tightly packed, finely-ground coffee at high pressure, creating a small but potent shot of coffee.

Flavor Profile: Espresso is intense, full-bodied, and aromatic, with a complex flavor profile that can range from sweet to bitter.

Pro Tip: Use freshly ground coffee and ensure your espresso machine is properly calibrated for the best results. The grind size, tamping pressure, and water temperature are key to pulling the perfect shot.

6. Cold Brew: Smooth and Refreshing

Overview: Cold brew coffee is made by steeping coarse coffee grounds in cold water for an extended period, usually 12-24 hours. It’s a refreshing alternative to hot coffee, especially during the warmer months.

Best For: Anyone who loves a smooth, less acidic coffee that can be enjoyed over ice.

How It Works: Coarse coffee grounds are mixed with cold water and left to steep at room temperature or in the fridge. The coffee is then filtered, producing a concentrate that can be diluted with water or milk.

Flavor Profile: Cold brew is known for its smooth, mellow flavor and low acidity. It’s less bitter than traditional iced coffee, making it a popular choice for those who prefer a milder taste.

Pro Tip: Cold brew concentrate can be stored in the fridge for up to two weeks, making it a convenient option for busy mornings. Mix it with water or milk in a 1:1 ratio for a ready-to-drink cold brew.

Conclusion: Find Your Brew

With so many brewing methods to choose from, there’s a perfect cup of coffee waiting for everyone. Whether you’re drawn to the convenience of a drip coffee maker, the full-bodied richness of a French press, or the smooth refreshment of cold brew, each method offers a unique way to experience the magic of coffee. Experimenting with different brewing techniques is not only fun but can also deepen your appreciation for the craft of coffee-making. So grab your favorite beans, pick a method, and start brewing!

The Ultimate Coffee Cocktail


If you’re a coffee enthusiast with a penchant for mixology, you’re in for a treat. Imagine the rich, aromatic depths of your favorite coffee blending seamlessly with the sophisticated flair of a cocktail. This isn't just a fleeting idea—it's the essence of the Ultimate Coffee Cocktail, a drink that bridges the worlds of java and spirits in a beautifully balanced concoction.


Ingredients

  • 142ml carton double cream
  • 5 tbsp Baileys
  • 125ml strong coffee, cooled
  • 4 tbsp vodka
  • 4 tbsp Kahlúa
  • coffee beans, to decorate, optional
  • biscuits of your choice, to serve


Method

STEP 1

Lightly whip the cream until slightly thickened, then stir in the Baileys and whip a little more, or thin if necessary with a little water, to get a thick, creamy pouring consistency.


STEP 2

Divide the coffee, vodka and Kahlúa between 4 glasses. Carefully spoon over the cream and sprinkle with a few coffee beans to decorate if you like. Serve with biscuits of your choice – Italian amaretti or biscotti would be perfect.
